qas.question: What is undisputed about early humans?
Hunting was important for the emergence of the Homo genus from what?
Production of stone tools and control of fire were also pushed forward by what?
What became a theme of stories and myths?
Hunting allowed what type of rituals?
What is undisputed about earlier humans?
What did hunting become a theme of?
Stone tools and control of fire are emphasised in what hypothesis?
What kind of activity would require the use of fire for early humans?
Mating behavior was important for the emergence of Homo genus from what?
What did omnivory become a theme of for early man?
What was animal sacrifice considered to be as part of the emergence of modern humans?
What is undisputed about animals that were sacrificed?

context: While it is undisputed that early <a5_0>humans <a0_0><b12_0>were hunters<b12_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>, the importance of this for the emergence of the Homo genus from the <a1_0><b9_0>earlier Australopithecines<b9_0/><a1_0/>, including the production of stone tools and eventually the control of fire, are emphasised in the <a2_0><a7_0>hunting<a2_0/> hypothesis<a7_0/> and de-emphasised in scenarios that stress omnivory and social interaction, including mating behaviour, as <b11_0>essential<b11_0/> in the emergence of human behavioural modernity. With the establishment of language, culture, and religion, <a3_0>hunting<a3_0/> became a theme of <a6_0><b10_0>stories and myths<b10_0/><a6_0/>, as well as rituals such as <a4_0>dance and <b8_0>animal sacrifice<b8_0/><a4_0/>.
